comment: Never actually owned this one; just have some counters from this game.

Comments are based on the First Edition. The Coalition has more ships, more money, and a better production schedule. With a predictable and consistent percentage based combat system, when does the miracle happen for the Allies? Never. In short, the game is solvable with the right mix of builds and repairs for the Coalition.

The designer clearly assumed the Klingons would be attrited from a massive Kzinti homeworld assault. Instead, the Klingon player can use the Lyrans for cannon fodder on the outlying systems and pin the rest of the Kzinti fleet on their homeworld while building a massive fleet to swarm the Federation player with.

That, combined with an absurdly lengthy rulebook (I've read that the 2010 version is up to 146 pages), gobs of counters, obscene playing time, excessive record keeping and a complete lack of strategic command & control, make this game a complete turd.

I thought I would really love this game. Hex and chit space wargame? That's exactly up my alley. Insanely complex? Bring it on! Except, unfortunately not. This game is not complex. It's insultingly simple.

From the moment you start reading the rules, one thing will start to become abundantly clear: you do not "play" Federation & Empire, not much anyway. I have the 2016 reprint with all the latest rules changes so this is the fairest review that can be given.

In F&E, what you actually do is faithfully remake the entire history of Star Trek, with a few minor accounting differences here and there. The game has an accounting ledger where you write in what you spend and where each turn. However, you can't build certain ships until certain turns, and you're just given them. Everything in the game is locked down by areas of space and turn count. It's like waiting until a certain time to be given permission to actually play this.

Underneath all that is clearly a robust wargame waiting to get out. Unfortunately, we couldn't even finish this because we were tired of playing "Mother May I" with a board game's rules. It was insulting from start to finish. Hard pass forever.

This is the hardest game I have had to rate, simply because of how sprawling it is. I've been playing it for several months now, so in a sane world and with a sane game, that would give me enough experience to fully feel out the system and feel confident in my judgement.

But we are talking about the madness that is Federation & Empire.

The game is very modular, so your group has the ultimate say on just how complex you want to make the game. That customizability is probably the best thing Federation & Empire has going for it. But it is also a rabbit hole filled with seemingly endless options. There are rules for just about every situation imaginable. And that, I admit, was part of the initial draw for me, but living it now is also overwhelming. Until you experience it, I don't think anyone can really prepare themselves for the amount of rules Federation & Empire brings to the table.

That said, I will not fault Federation & Empire for the scope of it's rules. No, it never claimed to be anything less than a comprehensive treatment of an interstellar war. Instead, I will focus on two main issues I have with the game: combat and freedom.

The combat in Federation & Empire has the feel of smashing toy spaceships together. It is one of the simplest aspects of the game, it drags on far past it's welcome, and there is a lot of it. You place your units on a battle board, the attacker and defender each roll a d6, and cross reference your roll with the total firepower of your ships on a percentage chart for how much damage you inflict on the other fleet. Repeat the process until one player retreats or is wiped out. There isn't a lot to it compared to the rest of Federation & Empire, and it becomes a slog. Now, you could fix this by playing out the battles via Starfleet Battles, which is great combat system, but then you have just raised the complexity of the game to the power of another game, and with the amount of ships and battles, beyond the scope of one person per power. It is a fix, but it is a fix turned up to 11.

My second issue with the game is freedom. From what I understand of the lore, Federation & Empire tells the story of how a interstellar war broke out among the great powers of our neck of the galaxy. So, when you play Federation & Empire, you are playing the story of not any war, but that specific war. The sides are locked in, there is no diplomacy, the entry of powers into the war is scripted, and you have scheduled of what units you can buy each specific turn. This is not a sandbox game, this is a re-enactment of a war that you would get in the same way if you were playing a wargame on WWII, for instance. But while I can get enjoyment from that style of game about events that actually happened, to do so with Federation & Empire I'd have to be more invested in the lore of Amarillo's Starfleet universe than I am.

Federation & Empire is really like nothing else. It is an experience, one that is going to last me a long time more. And I get to spend it with people I enjoy hanging out with. I do have fun with it, and I am sure I will have more fun with it. But after the war finishes, I don't think I will ever make such an investment into the game again.

I have the original 1986 version, which has the advantage of being somewhat streamlined (if you can use the word in relation to this game at all).

It is still very clunky, with many things that need to be recorded on paper. Definately not for the faint of heart. But, there is no other game quite like it, and if you want a wargame of the Star Trek universe, and an indepth one, this is the only game in town.

Still, I can't help but redesign, in my head, certain aspects of it every time I play. With just a little thought, this could be made a much better game.

(How about point tracks instead of written records for the economic aspects of the game?)
